thread.title: Exeter's 'double whammy' as leisure centre and bus station also put on hold

author: Phil Goodwin
title: Exeter's 'double whammy' as leisure centre and bus station also put on hold
text:
News Exeter's 'double whammy' as leisure centre and bus station also put on hold Cancellation of Princesshay extension followed by news that a deal to build new pool and bus station has also collapsed Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Comments 
Exeter's hoped-for city centre development has been hit by a "double whammy" after a deal to build the new leisure centre and bus station collapsed, the city council leader has revealed. 
It emerged on Monday morning that the Crown Estate had cancelled its plans to extend Princesshay shopping centre, citing "market conditions". 
This consigned to the rubbish bin an ambitious plan for a huge public space and amphitheatre across Paris Street into the old bus station and up to the back of Sidwell Street. 
Following this, Exeter City Council revealed that a contract with the firm lined up to build the state-of-the-art swimming pool and bus station, believed to be Sir Robert McAlpine, had not been signed. 
The authority has now walked away from the deal and plans to re-tender for both projects, adding a year to the completion date, now set at 2020. 
Asked if the two were connected, council leader Pete Edwards said the building firm may have been banking on securing the contract to construct the Princesshay extension. Pete Edwards, Exeter City Council leader 
"I don't know, maybe the builders were after the Crown Estate contract and now that's not going ahead...I don't know, nobody is saying anything," he told Devon Live. 
"I think the builders are probably genuinely scared of taking the risk. We have agreed a price and asked them to sign a contract but they won't sign. Who knows what the reasons are behind the scenes. 
"I did warn them if they didn't sign we would put it out to tender." 
Despite the setback, the council insists the ageing bus and coach station will permanently shut as planned. 
The 50-year-old facility will close after the last bus has left the station on Saturday, October 28. 
The council's new Exeter Bus Station was set to open in the winter of 2019, at the same time as its planned passivhaus leisure centre, a pool and gym complex built to strict design standards. 
However, the council-led £40m development of a section of the bus station site, creating St Sidwell's Point leisure complex and a new bus station, now needs a new builder. 
It will not be complete until at least 2020. 
In the meantime, temporary measures will be in place on the roads around the development site, including Sidwell Street and Cheeke Street. 
From Sunday, October 29, passengers will be picked up and dropped off at these dedicated bus stands. 
. 
The bus station was meant to close in March, but the project was put on hold after the council struggled to find a contractor within the constraints of their budget. 
Economic uncertainty around Brexit has been blamed for rising prices and the falling value of the pound may have made the leisure centre even more expensive. 
Cllr Edwards believes the exchange rate is making material from mainland Europe more expensive but has vowed to complete the project, dubbed by critics "Pete's Pool", "before he dies". 
"It is a double whammy and a disaster for the city," he added.

"I don't know whether costs have gone up because of Brexit; a lot of the building materials , especially the glass, come from Germany, maybe that's gone up because the pound's dropped. 
"I am determined to build this place before I die - stick with me and I will deliver it." 
The leader has suggested that the new city redevelopment around the bus station may move away from retail. 
"We have got a great opportunity because we won the bus station - maybe the market needs something else, maybe housing or offices as we a really short of good quality offices," he added. 
"We are closing the bus station on October 28 and we are going to continue with that." 
Prior to Monday's shock announcements, one of the major stumbling blocks to the Princesshay scheme was the contentious closure of Paris Street.

Objectors angry that re-routed traffic would cause gridlock elsewhere had forced a public enquiry, which could have scuppered the planning consent.
